Surrey BLDC

The extended guide to competing with Surrey BLDC.

New to all this? We guess you've got questions like...

I'm wondering if I want to compete—is it right for me?

If you love to dance, chances are good that you'll love competing as well. Read on to find out what you'll need to take to the circuit with us.

What's it like dancing in front of all those other people? Is it a bit scary?

Relax! We hear this from our beginners every year, but there's really nothing to worry about - it's all in the mind. Past members have always come out with a positive result and find they can't wait for the next competition!

Is your competition team selective, or do I have to qualify somehow?

Nope - our team is "unlimited" so that means if you want to compete, just get in touch and sign right up!

Shoes

General

If you are thinking about competing we recommend that you purchase proper dancing shoes with suede soles - they will significantly improve how you dance.

In all cases the competition organisers are quite keen to protect their floor surfaces, so they insist that all competitors wear non-marking shoes.

Guys

The first pair of shoes you buy should be ballroom shoes since they also work for the Latin American dances. (Seriously, big heel leads in Cuban heels lead to falling over.) Ballroom shoes have about a 1 inch heel, and get matte black ones - a conservative Oxford style pair should do nicely.

Girls

The opposite - your first pair should be Latin shoes as these can be worn to do ballroom dancing as well.

You will also need heel protectors for your shoes before the competitions. It is important to know the style of your heel to purchase the correct heel protectors; you can find this out when you buy the shoes.

Clothes

General

To make everything fairer at Beginner and Novice levels of the University competition circuit, all dancers must wear non-competitive dress - that means nothing with sparkles! But at Intermediate, Advanced and Ex Student levels, anything goes.

If you're not sure, we recommend you always get a member of committee, or a teacher, to check what you're going to wear beforehand.

Guys

A good place to start would be:

  • A crisp, clean, and ironed white shirt.
  • Black trousers (suit ones are fine).
  • Black socks (not white socks).
  • Matte black dance shoes, or or other smart shoes if you haven't got them.
  • A suit tie (you could match it to the colour of your partner's dress).

Girls

At Beginner and Novice levels, a dress or skirt and top is acceptable as long as they are unpatterned and do not contain rhinestones or fringing. For Ballroom, a longer skirt is required, although you may be able to borrow a Ballroom skirt from the club.

Hair

General

If your hair is naturally springy or bouncy, or if you have any tufts which stick up by themselves, you will need to tame it with the liberal application of hair gel. (A walking haystack doesn't impress the judges.)

Do not worry - there will be plenty of people to help you with your hair on the day if necessary!

Guys

We realise that for a lot of guys, "hair" is just the thing attached to your head which you don't really think about, but worry not - your committee and teachers can alleviate your confusion.

Girls

Your hair needs to be tied back in a tight bun, with all loose strands gelled/hair sprayed down, away from your face. Among other things this stops it swishing around and ending up all over your partner! A hair net is a good way to keep the bun neat and tidy, with lots of hair grips! You are allowed to add hair-slides with some sparkle or decoration on them.

Make-up and the 'T' word

Make-up

(This bit's largely for the benefit of the girls.)

Make-up needs to be quite heavy to make sure the lighting does not wash out your skin.

  • use foundation/bronzer on your face and don't spare it
  • eye shadow, eye liner and mascara all help to give off a professional look and first impressions mean everything in competitions
  • some lipstick will finish off the job perfectly

Tanning

Yeah, we just said it... don't laugh! Newsreaders and other people on TV do it to normalise their skin tone under the bright studio lights.

Competitions have similarly unforgiving lighting, so unless you have a suitably dark complexion naturally you'll look about as white as scared milk! This is where the wonders of artificial tanning come in to play... yes, even for the men.

If you have fair skin, you will need to either spray tan or use tinted moisturiser in the lead up to the competition. Don't worry though, you'll see that everyone else is more orange than you when you get there!

...and one obvious thing

Practice makes perfect

Every dancer out there

We said it was obvious! In the middle of all this crazy preparation, don't forget that the judges are mainly concerned with your dancing ability so ensure you get all the extra practice time that you can before a competition. Committee will usually lay on some extra sessions for this - just ask them when they are.
